DELETETHISLATER black

vehicle.name: 4.5in Static AA Mount
vehicle.description: Originally a twin-barreled Admiralty weapon, some of these were diverted for use in static land mountings by the Army. Part of the modification required removing the second barrel. Although the weapon was designated "4.5in", the actual calibre was 4.45in or 113mm. It was surrounded by a massive gun shield, which was in fact identical to that used on the navy ships.

vehicle.name: 50 kg Manpack
vehicle.description: Represents manpack and hand-cart carriage of ammunition, rations, water and equipment.

vehicle.name: 0.5 t Horse-drawn Wagon
vehicle.description: Specifications based on the German Hf 3 small field wagon series.

vehicle.name: 0.75 t Horse-drawn Wagon
vehicle.description: Specifications based on the German Hf 1 light field wagon series.

vehicle.name: 1 t Horse-drawn Wagon
vehicle.description: Specifications based on the German Hf 2 heavy field wagon series.

vehicle.name: Kuebelwagen
vehicle.description: German equivalent of the Jeep, though not as versatile.

vehicle.name: Kuebelwagen AA
vehicle.description: German equivalent of the Jeep, though not as versatile. This version mounted a dual MG for anti-aircraft defense.

vehicle.name: 3 t truck - Ger
vehicle.description: Typified by the famous Opel Blitz model (shown) of which more than 70,000 were built, the 3 tonner was the mainstay of German military transport during the war.

vehicle.name: Car - Bren AA LMG
vehicle.description: The Jeep is a legend. Eisenhower nominated it one of the three tools that enabled the Allies to win the war (along with the Dakota and landing craft). Cheap ($739 each), rugged and endlessly useful more than 653,000 were built during the war.

vehicle.name: Jeep - Vickers K MG
vehicle.description: One of the best known variants of the Jeep was the addition of machine guns. At Arnhem the 1st Airborne Reconnaissance Sqn Jeeps mounted a single Vickers K, although the armament was frequently heavier.

vehicle.name: 8 cwt truck
vehicle.description: This designation included a range of vehicles with similar characteristics. They were used for a variety of roles including command posts, radio trucks, and personnel carriers. The specifications of this vehicle are based on the Canadian General Motors C-8.

vehicle.name: Tractor Fd Arty (Quad)
vehicle.description: This designation included a range of vehicles with similar characteristics. They were used exclusively as artillery and ammunition carriers. The specifications of this vehicle are based on the Canadian General Motors C-GT.

vehicle.name: Jeep
vehicle.description: The Jeep is a legend. Eisenhower nominated it one of the three tools that enabled the Allies to win the war (along with the Dakota and landing craft). Cheap ($739 each), rugged and endlessly useful more than 653,000 were built during the war.

vehicle.name: 30 cwt truck
vehicle.description: This designation included a range of vehicles with similar characteristics. They were used for a variety of roles including cargo and personnel carriers. The specifications of this vehicle are based on the Canadian General Motors C-30.

vehicle.name: 15 cwt portee
vehicle.description: This designation included a range of vehicles with similar characteristics. They were used for a variety of roles including command posts, radio trucks, cargo, water, and personnel carriers. In this case the vehicle was modified to mount a 2pdr AT gun on the tray. The gun could be fired from the truck but in static positions was winched to the ground to improve concealment and cover.

vehicle.name: 3 ton truck
vehicle.description: This designation included a range of vehicles with similar characteristics. They were used for a variety of roles including cargo, water, and personnel carriers. The specifications of this vehicle are based on the Canadian General Motors C-60L.

vehicle.name: 15 cwt truck
vehicle.description: This designation included a range of vehicles with similar characteristics. They were used for a variety of roles including command posts, radio trucks, cargo, water, and personnel carriers. The specifications of this vehicle are based on the Canadian General Motors C-15A.

vehicle.name: 3 ton portee
vehicle.description: Portees are trucks modified to fit an artillery piece in the tray instead of a cargo or personnel-carrying body. The British and Commonwealth armies used portees throughout the war in a variety of roles, as a dedicated AA carrier, and as a makeshift SP AT gun system. In almost all cases the gun could either fire from the truck tray or be winched off the truck in order to fire it from a ground-deployed position, sacrificing mobility for cover and concealment.

vehicle.name: DUKW
vehicle.description: A truly inspirational creation, the DUKW gave Allied forces improved flexibility, especially in the Pacific. But they were also used widely in Europe, particularly in the Low Countries. More than 20,000 were built and 2,000 were sent to Britain.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 221 AC - MG
vehicle.description: This very light four-wheeled armoured car was based on a commercial 4WD chassis, the Horch 801. It mounted an open turret with a single MG 34 machine gun. Two other armoured vehicles used this chassis: the SdKfz 222, which mounted a 2cm cannon, and the SdKfz 223, which was essentially the same vehicle but with a more powerful radio fit.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 222 AC - 2cm gun
vehicle.description: This very light four-wheeled armoured car was based on a commercial 4WD chassis, the Horch 801. In this version it mounted a larger turret containing a 2cm gun. Two other armoured cars used the same chassis: the SdKfz 221, which mounted only an LMG, and the SdKfz 223, which was essentially the SdKfz 221 with a more powerful radio fit.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 223 AC - MG
vehicle.description: This very light four-wheeled armoured car was based on a commercial 4WD chassis, the Horch 801. It mounted an open turret with a single MG 34 machine gun. Two other armoured vehicles used this chassis: the SdKfz 222, which mounted a 2cm cannon, and the SdKfz 221, which was essentially the same vehicle but with a more powerful radio fit.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 231 AC - 2cm gun
vehicle.description: This light armoured car was based on a commercial Daimler-Benz G 3 6X4 chassis. This chassis was then armoured and an enclosed turret mounting a 2cm gun and a coaxial MG 34 machine gun was fitted. The SdKfz (Fu) 232 was the same vehicle but with a powerful 100 watt radio and frame aerial fitted and somewhat lighter frontal armour.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 232 AC - 2cm gun
vehicle.description: This light armoured car was based on a commercial Daimler-Benz G 3 6X4 chassis. This chassis was then armoured and an enclosed turret mounting a 2cm gun and a coaxial MG 34 machine gun was fitted. The SdKfz 232 was the same vehicle as the SdKfz 231, but with a powerful 100 watt radio and frame aerial fitted, and somewhat lighter frontal armour.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 234/1 AC
vehicle.description: An improved design of armoured car, the 234/1 was introduced in July 1944 and served in the Recon Bns of Panzer and Panzer Grenadier divisions. It proved a very effective reconnaissance vehicle. 200 were built.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 234/2 Puma AC
vehicle.description: The best all-round armoured car of the war: terrific gun, mobility and protection. The Puma was designed to operate in the hot climates of North Africa and the steppes of Russia. Only 101 were built from September 1943 to September 1944.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 247 Personnel AC
vehicle.description: A very lightly armoured, unarmed vehicle, used in the motorcycle (Kradschuetz) battalions.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 260 Radio AC
vehicle.description: This very light four-wheeled armoured car was based on a commercial 4WD chassis, the Horch 801. In this version, and in the very similar SdKfz 261, the armament was removed to make way for a more powerful radio fit and signals personnel.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 261 Radio AC
vehicle.description: This very light four-wheeled armoured car was based on a commercial 4WD chassis, the Horch 801. In this version, and in the very similar SdKfz 260, the armament was removed to make way for a more powerful radio fit and signals personnel.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 263 Command AC - MG
vehicle.description: This light armoured command car was based on the SdKfz 232. The turret was fixed in place and the 2cm main armament deleted, while additional radio equipment and another crew member (to operate the radios) were added. This version lacked the thicker frontal armour of the SdKfz 231.

vehicle.name: Morris CS9 LRC
vehicle.description: The Morris CS9 armoured car was a converted Morris 4x2, 15-cwt truck, and was a stopgap until better designs became available. 99 were built in 1938 and 38 saw service with 12th Royal Lancers in France 1940 and another 30 sent to North Africa, serving with 11th Hussars as part of a Rolls Royce equipment unit. It remained in service until 1943.

vehicle.name: Rolls Royce 1924 Mk I AC
vehicle.description:
The Rolls Royce Armoured Car was veteran of the First World War. The vehicles were constructed on standard Rolls Royce Silver Ghost chassis, on which a steel superstructure was built, with a revolving turret on top.
By 1939, 150 cars were is service, with many in Britain for home defence, but over half were in the Middle East or India. Several were used in Syria, in 1941, and also in the early desert campaigns of that year. Before they were withdrawn from service in 1941 the cars were fitted with an open topped turret and re-armed with theBoys Anti-Tank Rifle to provide additional firepower, with a light machine gun or twin Vickers K guns on the top of the turret.

vehicle.name: Marmon-Harrington AC
vehicle.description: Based on a Ford 3-ton truck chassis, fitted with a conversion kit from the Marmon-Harrington firm, these were originally intended for the South African Army. In the end they were used extensively in the Western Desert, both by the South Africans and by the British. They were generally fitted with Vickers MMG and a Boys Anti-Tank Rifle.

vehicle.name: Daimler Mk II AC
vehicle.description: Principal armoured car of British Recce Troops

vehicle.name: SdKfz 2 Kettenkrad
vehicle.description: The SdKfz 2 became very popular in Russia because of its excellent mobility in appalling conditions. It was widely used as a light transport and messenger vehicle.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 6
vehicle.description: The 5 tonne SdKfz 6 unarmoured half-track was intended to be the prime mover for the leFH 18 and for engineer units. It proved to be more expensive than alternative vehicles and was phased out in 1941. 3500 were produced.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 6/2 - 3.7cm AA
vehicle.description: An effective combination of the 3.7cm Flak 36 gun on the SdKfz 6 half-track. The 6/2 served mainly with Luftwaffe flak units. 339 were built until mid-1943. The gun was later mounted on the SdKfz 7 half-track.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 7
vehicle.description: Designed to tow 8 tonnes, the SdKfz 7 is best known as the prime mover for the famous 88mm flak gun. It entered service in 1934 and remained in production throughout the war. Nearly 8,000 were built.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 7/1 - Flakvierling
vehicle.description: This was a highly effective combination of the four-barrelled 20mm Flakvierling gun on an SdKfz 7 half-track. As well flak defence it provided terrifying firepower in the direct fire role. 319 were built until October 1944.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 8
vehicle.description: Designed to tow 12 tonnes, the SdKfz 8 was the first German halftrack to be produced. It was used to tow the heaviest artillery equipment.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 10
vehicle.description: The lightest of the unarmoured German half-tracks (with a tow capacity of 1 tonne) the SdKfz 10 entered service in 1938. Some 25,000 were built until 1944. It towed PaK and light flak guns and served as the chassis for the SdKfz 250 armoured half-track.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 10/4 - 2cm AA
vehicle.description: The 10/4 was the first German SP flak gun, using the 2cm Flak 38 on the SdKfz 10 half-track. 610 were built and were used by Wehrmacht and Luftwaffe flak units. Although halftracks are typically thought of as an armoured vehicle, the SdKfz 10 series were in fact soft-skinned and therefore vulnerable to even small-arms fire.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 11
vehicle.description: The main prime mover for the FH 18 105mm howitzer and the PaK 40 anti-tank gun, the SdKfz 11 (3 tonne) entered service in 1938. It was an extremely versatile vehicle and remained in production throughout the war. Some 41,000 were built. It formed the basis for the ubiquitous SdKfz 251 armoured half-track and the Maultier self-propelled Nebelwerfer.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 250/1 - MG
vehicle.description: The 250 was the second APC to be developed. It was used mainly by reconnaissance units and as a command vehicle. Some 7,500 were built.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 250/8 - 7.5cm gun
vehicle.description: This combination of the 7.5cm KwK 37 L24 gun on the SdKfz 250 chassis first appeared in early 1943. They were issued to light reconnaissance companies.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 250/9 - 2cm AA
vehicle.description: Began mass production in May 1943 as a replacement for the SdKfz 222 armoured car due to its better cross-country mobility.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 250/10 - 3.7cm AT
vehicle.description: This combination of the 3.7cm PaK 36 on the SdKfz 250 chassis was used by platoon commanders in reconnaissance units for direct fire support.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/1 - MG
vehicle.description: The first armoured personnel carrier, the 251 was the principal vehicle of panzer grenadier regiments from 1941. Extremely versatile, it was adapted to carry a variety of weapons. Some 16,000 were built.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/2 - 8cm mor
vehicle.description: This combination of the 8cm mortar mounted in the SdKfz 251 chassis was issued to the heavy platoon in armoured infantry companies.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/7 - PzB
vehicle.description: The first armoured personnel carrier, the 251 was the principal vehicle of panzer grenadier regiments from 1941. Extremely versatile, it was adapted to carry a variety of weapons. Some 16,000 were built. The SdKfz 251/7 added an anti-tank rifle (PzB or Panzerbuechse) to the normal MG armament and was commonly used by armoured engineer units.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/9 - 7.5cm gun
vehicle.description: This combination of the old 7.5cm KwK 37 L24 (from early model PzKw IVs) on the SdKfz 251 chassis appeared in late 1942 in the Heavy companies of Panzer Grenadier battalions. Also known as the Stummel (Stump).

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/10 - 3.7cm AT
vehicle.description: This combination of the 3.7cm PaK 36 on the SdKfz 251 entered service in 1940. It was ssued to platoon commanders to provide heavy fire support.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/16 - FT
vehicle.description: The first armoured personnel carrier, the 251 was the principal vehicle of panzer grenadier regiments from 1941. The SdKfz 251/16 mounted two flamethrowers in addition to the usual pair of MGs.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/17 - 2cm AA
vehicle.description: This was a 20mm Flak 38 gun on the SdKfz 251 chassis. It was used by both Wehrmacht and Luftwaffe units.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/21 - 15mm AA
vehicle.description: This was a SdKfz 251 boasting a triple mount of MG 151/15 AA machine guns. It was used mainly to provide low-level flak defence for mechanised units.

vehicle.name: M3 HT - 50/30 cal MGs
vehicle.description: Like its German equivalents the M3 proved an extremely versatile and successful vehicle which was adapted for a broad range of reconnaissance, combat, transport and support roles. More than 41,000 were built until mid-1944.

vehicle.name: M3 HT - 30 cal MG
vehicle.description: Like its German equivalents the M3 proved an extremely versatile and successful vehicle which was adapted for a broad range of reconnaissance, combat, transport and support roles. More than 41,000 were built until mid-1944.

vehicle.name: FlakPz IV Moebelwagen
vehicle.description: An interim design intended to fill in for more advanced flak tanks, the Moebelwagen mounted a 3.7cm Flak gun on an PzKw IV chassis. These were issued to Pz Divs stationed on the Western Front and proved adequate in combat.

vehicle.name: FlakPz IV Wirbelwind
vehicle.description: A deadly SP flak weapon, the Wirbelwind provided close flak defence for panzer regiments. It combined the ferocious four-barrelled 2cm Flakvierling gun on a Pz IV chassis. 86 were converted between July and November 1944.

vehicle.name: SP 7.5cm inf how
vehicle.description: Self-propelled 7.5cm Inf How based on Czech T38 chassis. First produced in Sep 1942. Only lightly armoured and open topped. Issued to PG Regt in Pz Divs.

vehicle.name: StuG III B
vehicle.description: An early version of the famous German assault gun series. The StuG III B mounted a short-barreled 7.5cm gun and was also designated the SdKfz 142, differentiating it from the later StuG III versions which were designated SdKfz 142/1 and mounted a long-barrelled L48 7.5cm gun.

vehicle.name: StuG III G
vehicle.description: Often referred to as a tank, the StuG was a versatile weapon, excellent at supporting infantry in both attack and defence. It was cheap to build and more than 8,500 were produced with the 7.5cm L48 gun from March 1942. It was also designated SdKfz 142/1 which distinguished it from the earlier versions (designated SdKfz 142) which were fitted with a short-barrelled L24 7.5cm gun.

vehicle.name: SP 15cm sIG 33
vehicle.description: An ungainly-looking field adaptation, this vehicle took the entire chassis of a PzKw I B, and mounted an entire sIG 33 infantry gun - complete with carriage and wheels - in a fixed, open-topped armoured housing. Only 38 were produced. The vehicle was never given a numeric designation (SdKfz number).

vehicle.name: SdKfz 138/1 - sIG 33
vehicle.description: Self-propelled 15cm Inf Gun based on PzKw 38(t) chassis. First produced in Sep 1942. Only lightly armoured and open topped. Issued to PG Regt in Pz Divs.

vehicle.name: 102/35 AT gun-portee
vehicle.description: 102/35 AA gun mounted on a Fiat 634 3 ton truck. Only 7 were built, from guns salvaged from Tobruk Harbour. Used with great success at Bir El Gubi in late 1941. All were eventually lost due to air attack and mechanical breakdown.

vehicle.name: Semovente L40 da 47/32 SPG
vehicle.description: This light self-propelled gun was based on the L6/40 chassis and mounted the ubiquitous 47mm modello 35 gun.

vehicle.name: Semovente M41 da 75/18 SPG
vehicle.description: Brainchild of Colonel Borlese, of the Italian artillery, this early assault gun was intended for use in indirect fire tasks as well anti-tank and infantry support. It proved effective against the M3 Grant and M4 Sherman in the desert war, thanks to the good gun and HESH anti-tank ammunition.

vehicle.name: Semovente M41M da 90/53 SPG
vehicle.description: Produced in 1942, this self-propelled tank destroyed was based on the chassis of the M13/41 medium tank. The gun and shield were mounted at the rear of the vehicle, which only carried eight rounds of ready ammunition, while the engine was shifted to the front. It towed a trailer containing a further 40 rounds, and was always accompanied in the field by converted L6/40 tanks which carried 26 rounds of ammunition.

vehicle.name: Carro Armato L6 Cargo
vehicle.description: This conversion featured the Carro Armato L6/40 stripped of armament so as to carry the ammunition for the Semovente M41M da 90/53.

vehicle.name: SP 4.7cm Pak 36 (t)
vehicle.description: The first of the German SP anti-tank guns, this was a captured Czech 4.7cm AT gun mounted on the chassis of a PzKw I B.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 132 - 7.62cm AT gun
vehicle.description: Already obsolete by the start of the war, the PzKw II nevertheless comprised a significant part of Germany's tank arsenal. Later in the war it was relegated to recconaissance duties only. In some cases it was stripped and mounted with a rebuilt Russian field gun, the 7.62cm Pak 36 (r).

vehicle.name: JgPz IV/70
vehicle.description: A formidable tank destroyer. The JgPz IV/70 combined the proven Pz IV chassis with the superb 7.5cm L70 gun. Its low silhouette made it very dangerous. It entered combat service in August 1944. About 1,000 were built.

vehicle.name: JgPz V Jagdpanther
vehicle.description: The best all-round tank destroyer of the war. The Jagdpanther combined the Panther chassis with the 8.8cm Pak43 gun. Low silhouette, excellent sloping armour plate and the premier hard hitting "88" made it very lethal indeed. It entered combat service in February 1944.

vehicle.name: Archer
vehicle.description: In early 1943 the 17 pdr was the first British or US gun in the same league as German 75mm weapons. Trouble was hardly any Brit or US tanks could mount the weapon. As a stop-gap the gun was mounted backwards on a Valentine chassis. The Archer appeared in combat from October 1944.

vehicle.name: Achilles
vehicle.description: British version of the American M10 tank destroyer but armed with a 17pdr gun. Based on an Sherman chasis.

vehicle.name: PzKw I B
vehicle.description: A very light tank, initially intended as a training vehicle for PzKw II crews, but actually comprised a substantial proportion of the German tank forces on the outbreak of war. Only a few of these were still in service by the time of the Balkan campaign.

vehicle.name: PzKw I F (VK 1801)
vehicle.description: A very light tank, initially intended as a training vehicle for PzKw II crews, but actually comprised a substantial proportion of the German tank forces on the outbreak of war. The VK 1801 or Ausf. F was a heavy assault version of the tank, over three times the weight of the original versions, and much slower. Only 30 were built, of which five were allocated to the invasion of Malta.

vehicle.name: kl PzBefWg
vehicle.description: A command tank based on the PzKw I B chassis, this vehicle added powerful radios but removed the turret and one MG.

vehicle.name: PzKw II A / B / C
vehicle.description: Already obsolete by the start of the war, the PzKw II nevertheless comprised a significant part of Germany's tank arsenal. Later in the war it was relegated to recconaissance duties only.

vehicle.name: PzKw 38(t) A / B / C / D
vehicle.description: PzKw 38(t) A / B / C / D

vehicle.name: PzKw II J (VK 1601)
vehicle.description: Already obsolete by the start of the war, the PzKw II nevertheless comprised a significant part of Germany's tank arsenal. Later in the war it was relegated to reconaissance duties only. This version was a prototype aimed at creating a better fast reconnaissance tank and only 22 were built. Eventually the variety of designs resulted in the PzKw II L Luchs, which was a successful light reconnaissance tank.

vehicle.name: Somua S-35
vehicle.description: Somua S-35

vehicle.name: Hotchkiss H-35
vehicle.description: Hotchkiss H-35

vehicle.name: PzKw B-2 (f)
vehicle.description: The Char B-1 was the principal medium tank of the French Army in 1940. Most were destroyed or damaged during the German invasion in May-June 1940. The Germans converted 60 Char B1-bis tanks to carry a flamethrower in place of the hull 7.5cm gun.

vehicle.name: PzKw III E
vehicle.description: The Pz III was the main German medium tank at the start of the war. Originally armed with the 3.7cm KwK 36 L45 gun, regular upgrades kept it in combat till mid-1943. After that it was relegated to reserve and training units. 349 PzKw III E fought in the French campaign in 1940; the PzKw III F was essentially the same vehicle. Eventually all of these tanks were later upgunned with the 5cm KwK 38 L/42 and fitted with extra armour plates. The first 50 PzKw III G models were also manufactured with the 3.7cm gun and no extra armour panels, but were all later upgraded.

vehicle.name: PzKw III H - KwK 38
vehicle.description: The Pz III was the main German medium tank at the start of the war. Originally armed with the 3.7cm KwK 35/36 L46.5 gun, regular upgrades kept it in combat till mid-1943. After that it was relegated to reserve and training units. 349 PzKw III E fought in the French campaign in 1940; the PzKw III F was essentially the same vehicle. Eventually all of these tanks were later upgunned with the 5cm KwK 38 L42. The first 50 PzKw III G models were also manufactured with the 3.7cm gun and no extra armour panels, but were all later upgraded. The PzKw III H were manufactured from the start with the 5cm KwK 38 L42 and had additional armour panels.

vehicle.name: PzBefWg III
vehicle.description: A command-tank version of the PzKw III E, with the turret fixed in place and only one MG. A dummy gun was fitted to help disguise this vehicle from the enemy.

vehicle.name: PzKw III J - KwK 39
vehicle.description: The Pz III was the main German medium tank at the start of the war. The PzKw III H was the first variant to be produced throughout with a KwK 38 L42 5cm gun; from 1942, these were all gradually refitted with the KwK 39 L60 5cm gun which was more effective against armour. Early versions of the PzKw III J (SdKfz 141) were fitted with the short 5cm gun, while late versions (SdKfz 141/1) were fitted with the long gun.

vehicle.name: PzKw III J
vehicle.description: The Pz III was the main German medium tank at the start of the war. Regular upgrades kept it in combat till mid-1943. After that it was relegated to reserve and training units. Some 1,970 were built with the 5cm L60 gun. The PzKw III J model featured thicker armour than previous variants.

vehicle.name: PzKw IV D - KwK 37
vehicle.description: The Pz IV was the mainstay of the Pz divisions, serving (with regular improvement) throughout the war. The PzKw IV D was the first large-scale production model featuring various improvements over the pre-production designs (PzKw IV A, B and C). 229 were made and they saw service in France, North Africa, the Balkans, and on the Eastern Front. Many were fitted with extra armour plates on the hull. In 1943 some of these were upgunned with the KwK 40 L48 7.5cm gun.

vehicle.name: PzKw IV D - Malta
vehicle.description: The Pz IV was the mainstay of the Pz divisions, serving (with regular improvement) throughout the war. The PzKw IV D was the first large-scale production model featuring various improvements over the pre-production designs (PzKw IV A, B and C). 229 were made and they saw service in France, North Africa, the Balkans, and on the Eastern Front. Many were fitted with extra armour plates on the hull. 12 such examples, with 80mm frontal plate, were produced for the projected Malta invasion.

vehicle.name: PzKw IV H
vehicle.description: The Pz IV was the mainstay of the Pz divisions, serving (with regular improvement) throughout the war. The H and the J were the last models. Though old designs they were superior to the Allied Shermans and Cromwells. 3,774 Ausf H were built from April 1943 to July 1944.

vehicle.name: PzKw V Panther
vehicle.description: The best all-round tank of the war, combining excellent sloped armour with good mobility and the deadly 7.5cm L70 gun. Each Pz Division was meant have one Panther bn, but they were rarely up to strength. The Panther's major weakness was its complexity which affected its reliability. About 6,000 were built.

vehicle.name: PzKw KV-IA 753 (r)
vehicle.description: This was a captured KV-IA Soviet tank, mounting the long 76.2mm L41.5 F-34 gun. The Germans replaced the commander's cupola, lights and other items of running gear, and issued better ammunition for the gun. Ten of these tanks (or possibly a different version of KV-series tank as sources are unclear) were sent to the 2nd Pz Coy of Pz-Abt.zBV.66 (Special Purpose Tank Battalion 66) and were slated for the invasion of Malta. The armour figures here are an averaged estimate given the great variation between sources and variants of these tanks. Although the theoretical maximum speed was 35km/h, the Germans found the gearbox could only be engaged at the halt, slowing the vehicle greatly.

vehicle.name: PzKw KV-II 754 (r)
vehicle.description: This was a captured KV-II Soviet tank, mounting a 152mm howitzer. The Germans replaced the commander's cupola, lights and other items of running gear. Ten of these tanks (or possibly a different version of KV-series tank as sources are unclear) were sent to the 2nd Pz Coy of Pz-Abt.zBV.66 (Special Purpose Tank Battalion 66) and were slated for the invasion of Malta. The armour figures here are an averaged estimate given the great variation between sources and variants of these tanks. Although the theoretical maximum speed was 35km/h, the Germans found the gearbox could only be engaged at the halt, slowing the vehicle greatly.

vehicle.name: PzKw VI E Tiger I
vehicle.description: Such was its reputation that "Tiger" became the generic term used by Allied troops for all German armour. Introduced into combat in August 1942 it was a fiercesome machine with heavy armour and the excellent 8.8cm gun (a variant of the infamous flak/anti-tank gun). It suffered, however, from poor mobility and reliability. 1,354 were built.

vehicle.name: PzKw VI B Tiger II
vehicle.description: The most awesome tank of the war, the King Tiger combined excellent sloped armour with the superb 8.8cm L71 gun which could destroy Shermans out to 3000m. But this leviathon was troubled by poor mobility and reliability. It was also too little and too late. 489 were built and entered combat service in June 1944, when things were already out of hand.

vehicle.name: Carro Veloce 33/35 lt tank
vehicle.description: Designed for reconnaissance and security, this diminutive vehicle was already outclassed when Italy invaded Ethiopia. Several were captured during the abortive Italian attack on Greece and were then used by the Greek Army as a fledgling cavalry force.

vehicle.name: Carro Armato L6/40 tank
vehicle.description:
Intended as a larger replacement for the CV 33, this developed through a series of prototypes until it took on final form as a fairly conventional turreted vehicle with torsion bar suspension and bolted and rivetted armour. Although the design was originally intended to carry a 37mm gun, the production model was only equipped with a 20mm main armament. Production started in 1939. Like most very light tanks it suffered from the disadvantage of a single-man turret.
First formation which used this tank in significant numbers was 3rd Group of regiment Lancieri di Novara, which was sent to North Africa as armored group of armored division Littorio in Spring 1942. L6/40 was usually given to the reconnaissance formation of Italian army and were also used in USSR, Sicily. Some were used in Yugoslavia against partisans, were several captured and used against previous owners.

vehicle.name: Carro Armato M11/39 tank
vehicle.description: Only 92 M11/39's were produced, around 70 of these being sent to Libya equipping the I and II Medium Tank Battalions (Battaglioni Catti M) and the rest to East Africa. The main 37mm armament was located in the hull, with a very restricted traverse. Although designed to carry a radio, none of the production vehicles was so equipped and coordination was conducted by radio in side car fitted motorcycles. There were no operational M11/39 remaining in Libya when Operation Compass began in early 1941.

vehicle.name: Carro Armato M13/40 tank
vehicle.description: Designed in 1939 this was issued as part of the Italian rearmament plan. These were the best of the Italian tanks in the early-war period, although still no match for the Matilda. It was unusually heavily-armed with machine guns. 779 were built in total and over 100 of these were captured at the battle of Beda Fomm, later being used to re-equip 6 RTR and 6 Au Inf Div Cav. A more reliable version with upgraded running gear was also produced and known as the M13/41.

vehicle.name: Carro Armato M14/41 tank
vehicle.description: The M14/41 was a more reliable version of the M13 with upgraded running gear.

vehicle.name: Vickers Mk VI lt tank
vehicle.description: The Vickers Mk VI was the most widely used of the early British light tanks. They were originally intended for use in colonial policing and reconnaissance, roles in which they might have been capable, but were often thrown into offensive actions in which they were little more than mobile coffins.

vehicle.name: Cruiser Mk IIA (A10) CS
vehicle.description: Designed before the war as an infantry tank, the Cruiser Mk IIA (also known as the A10) was based on the earlier and lighter Mk I (A9) but added extra armour by bolting additional plates on to the hull and turret. It was thus the first Allied tank to make use - albeit unintentionally - of spaced armour. However, by 1938 the tank was already too lightly armoured to meet the revised infantry tank specification and in the end it became largely regarded as an interim vehicle. In the CS version a 3.7in mortar, firing smoke only, was mounted instead of the normal 2 pdr. 30 were built in total.

vehicle.name: Cruiser Mk IIA (A10)
vehicle.description: Designed before the war as an infantry tank, the Cruiser Mk IIA (also known as the A10) was based on the earlier and lighter Mk I (A9) but added extra armour by bolting additional plates on to the hull and turret. It was thus the first Allied tank to make use - albeit unintentionally - of spaced armour. However, by 1938 the tank was already too lightly armoured to meet the revised infantry tank specification and in the end it became largely regarded as an interim vehicle. 162 were built in total.

vehicle.name: Cruiser Mk I (A9) CS
vehicle.description: The original 'cruiser' tank design, developed while the War Office was revising it's policy on the deployment of tanks. Produced in 1937, the A9 was the first British tank to have power traverse for the turret. Used in France by the 1st Armoured Division in 1940 where nearly all of them were left behind at Dunkirk. Also used by the 2nd and 7th Armoured Division in North Africa although by 1941 the lightly armoured A9 was obsolete, eventually being replaced by the A10. The CS version mounted a 3.7mm howitzer which could only fire smoke.

vehicle.name: Cruiser Mk I (A9)
vehicle.description: The original 'cruiser' tank design, developed while the War Office was revising it's policy on the deployment of tanks. Produced in 1937, the A9 was the first British tank to have power traverse for the turret. Used in France by the 1st Armoured Division in 1940 where nearly all of them were left behind at Dunkirk. Also used by the 2nd and 7th Armoured Division in North Africa, although by 1941 the lightly armoured A9 was obsolete, eventually being replaced by the A10.

vehicle.name: Crusader Mk I (A15) CS
vehicle.description: The Cruiser MKVI or A15 Crusader was developed as a heavy Cruiser tank. Although uncomfortable to ride in and somewhat unreliable, The Crusader (A15) was a welcome improvement over the earlier cruiser-type tanks. The first Crusader tanks went into battle during Operation Battleaxe, although the 2-pdr gun still proved inadequate against the german armour. The CS version mounted a 3.7 in Howitzer which was capable of diring smoke and HE ammunition.

vehicle.name: Crusader Mk I (A15)
vehicle.description: The Cruiser MKVI or A15 Crusader was developed as a heavy Cruiser tank. Although uncomfortable to ride in and somewhat unreliable, The Crusader (A15) was a welcome improvement over the earlier cruiser-type tanks. The first Crusader tanks went into battle during Operation Battleaxe, although the 2-pdr gun still proved inadequate against the german armour.

vehicle.name: Crusader Mk II (A15) CS
vehicle.description: The Cruiser MKVI or A15 Crusader was developed as a heavy Cruiser tank. Although uncomfortable to ride in and somewhat unreliable, The Crusader was a welcome improvement over the earlier cruiser-type tanks. The first Crusader tanks went into battle during Operation Battleaxe, although the 2-pdr gun still proved inadequate against the german armour. MK II version added additional armour on hull front and turret front. The CS version mounted a 3.7 in Howitzer which was capable of diring smoke and HE ammunition.

vehicle.name: Crusader Mk II (A15)
vehicle.description: The Cruiser MKVI or A15 Crusader was developed as a heavy Cruiser tank. Although uncomfortable to ride in and somewhat unreliable, The Crusader (A15) was a welcome improvement over the earlier cruiser-type tanks. The first Crusader tanks went into battle during Operation Battleaxe, although the 2-pdr gun still proved inadequate against the german armour. The MK II version added additional armour on hull front and turret front.

vehicle.name: Cruiser Mk IVA (A13 Mk II) CS
vehicle.description: An up-armoured version of the original Cruiser Mk IV (A13), and also known as the A13 Mk II, this was another example of a British tank where the addition of extra armour actually resulted in a spaced-armour effect, although this was not intentional at the time. Total production was 655 vehicles. In the CS version a 3.7in mortar, firing smoke only, replaced the normal 2pdr.

vehicle.name: Cruiser Mk IVA (A13 Mk II)
vehicle.description: An up-armoured version of the original Cruiser Mk IV (A13), and also known as the A13 Mk II, this was another example of a British tank where the addition of extra armour actually resulted in a spaced-armour effect, although this was not intentional at the time. Total production was 655 vehicles.

vehicle.name: Stuart Mk VI
vehicle.description: The Stuart light tank was armed with a 37mm Gun and two 30 cal MGs. Entered service in Feb 42. Produced in large numbers. Standard issue to British Recce Tps.

vehicle.name: Stuart Mk I
vehicle.description: The early production model M3 Stuart light tank or "Honey" as the British would call them, was armed with a 37mm Gun and three 30 cal MGs. This model of the M3 Entered service with the 4th Armored Brigade in time for Operation Crusader.

vehicle.name: Tetrarch Mk VII
vehicle.description: Initially designed for fast reconnaissance work, before the War Office moved in favour of using armoured cars in this role. Only 177 Tetrarchs were built, initially being issued to some armoured units to make up shortfalls in other types, and eventually placed in the Airborne - transported by the purpose-designed Hamilcar glider.

vehicle.name: Matilda Mk I (A11)
vehicle.description:
Designed to accompany infantry assaults at a walking pace, the Matilda was heavily armoured to withstand hits from tanks of the day. It was invulnerable to everything except the '88'. However it was painfully slow and very lightly armed. The Matilda I was used in France by the BEF, most notably during the counterattack at Arras. After Dunkirk the remaining Matilda I's in England were used for training purposes.
The 4/RTR had 50 Inf. Mk.I Matilda's in three companies. The sister unit, the 7/RTR, when it arrived in France in May 1940 had 27 Inf. Mk.I's and 23 Inf. Mk.II's (a much more potent weapon). Together, they shook the Germans at Arras, and allowed the BEF to escape to Dunkirk.

vehicle.name: Matilda Mk II (A12)
vehicle.description: Designed to accompany infantry assaults at a walking pace, the Matilda was heavily armoured to withstand hits from tanks of the day. In North Africa it was invulnerable to everything except the '88'. However it was painfully slow and very lightly armed.

vehicle.name: Valentine III
vehicle.description: Based on the A10 Cruiser tank, the Valentine was an attempt to combine the weight of a cruiser tank with the armour of an infantry tank, which resulted in a very small vehicle with a cramped interior and two-man turret. The Valentine III introduced a larger turret and additional crewman. The Valentine's armour was weaker than the Matilda's and shared the same top speed, however it was much less expensive and easier to produce.

vehicle.name: Matilda Mk II (A12) CS
vehicle.description: Designed to accompany infantry assaults at a walking pace, the Matilda was heavily armoured to withstand hits from tanks of the day. In North Africa it was invulnerable to everything except the '88'. However it was painfully slow and very lightly armed.

vehicle.name: Cromwell (A27M)
vehicle.description: The Cromwell was numerically the most important British cruiser tank of the war. By 1944 standards, however, it was a poor machine, and because of its poor design, could not be upgraded to match the late model PzKw IVs and Panthers. The "M" in "A27M" referred to the Meteor aircraft engine that powered the tank.

vehicle.name: Cromwell (A27M) CS
vehicle.description: This was a close support variant of the Cromwell, with a 32 pdr (95mm) tank howitzer. They were issued to tank squadron HQs. The "M" in "A27M" referred to the Meteor aircraft engine that powered the tank.

vehicle.name: Sherman 75
vehicle.description: The Sherman was an attempt to redress the perceived inferiority of British and US tanks. With a poor gun and armour, the Sherman nevertheless had virtues of simplicity, reliability, speed and ruggedness. It was also cheap which enabled it to be built in vast numbers. These factors enabled British and US armoured forces finally to defeat the German Army in the West by attrition.

vehicle.name: Sherman Firefly
vehicle.description: The Sherman's weak gun and armour had a bad effect on unit morale. The British answer was to instal a 17 pdr gun. The first Fireflies were ready for D-Day and soon proved their worth. Because of a shortage of 17 pdrs, Fireflies were issued one per troop.

vehicle.name: Challenger
vehicle.description: This was the first British effort to improve on the Sherman. But the project suffered many delays and was overtaken by the Sherman Firefly program. Some Challengers were issued to armoured reconnaissance squadrons in late 1944 but it was a poor vehicle.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 165 Hummel SPA
vehicle.description: Self-propelled 15cm How based on composite PzIII/PzIV chassis. First produced in Oct 1942. Only lightly armoured and open topped. Each Pz Div had an establishment of 6 Hummels.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 165 Cargo
vehicle.description: Hummel with the gun removed to carry ammunition and personnel.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 124 Wespe SPA
vehicle.description: Self-propelled 10.5cm How based on a PzII chassis. First produced in Dec 1942. Only lightly armoured and open topped. Each Pz Div had an establishment of 12 Wespes.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 124 Cargo
vehicle.description: Wespe with the gun removed to carry ammo. The gun could be refitted at a field workshop.

vehicle.name: Sexton SPA
vehicle.description: This was an "Anglicised" version of the US M7 (Priest). It was developed in late 1942 and carried a 25 pdr (in place of the US 105mm howitzer) on a Ram chassis. The Sexton was issued to the Field Regiments of Armoured Divisions. 2,150 were built.

weapon.name: Makeshift AT Bomb
weapon.description: This item represents a variety of makeshift AT bombs, such as Molotov Cocktails, or 'sticky bombs'.

weapon.name: 7.92mm PzB 38 AT rifle
weapon.description: A heavy, single-shot rifle, the Panzerbuechse 38 was the first anti-tank rifle issued to the German army after rearmament began in 1933. Penetration was improved after 1939 by using stocks of captured Polish tungsten-cored ammunition, but by 1941 the usefulness of all ATRs - not just the PzB 38 - was at an end.

weapon.name: PzFaust one-shot RPG
weapon.description: Way before its time, this was the original disposable weapon. Its punch was incredible but the range was desperately short and required nerves of steel.

weapon.name: PzSchreck RPG
weapon.description: Based on a captured American bazooka the PzSchreck with a 200m range and a leathal 3.3kg warhead was a weapon any Allied tanker had to respect.

weapon.name: 9mm Beretta m1918/30 SMG
weapon.description: A development of the Moschetto Automatico ("Automatic Carbine") OVP (itself an unusual twin-barrelled 1915 design, cut in half), the Moschetto Automatico Beretta modello 1918/30 used the Parabellum 9mm cartridge and had a high rate of fire. It was also fitted with a folding bayonet. It was similar to other early SMGs in that the overall shape of the weapon was that of a cut-down rifle, rather than the pistol-gripped design of later weapons of this class.

weapon.name: 6.5mm Breda m30 LMG
weapon.description: The Fucile Mitriagliatori ("Light Machine Gun") Breda modello 30 was the standard Italian LMG during the war. It was a poor weapon, which tended to jam due to the oiled-ammunition design. It was also handicapped by being fed from a hinged, permanently-attached 20-round magazine, which if damaged would prevent the weapon working. There was also no handle to facilitate barrel changes.

weapon.name: 8mm Fiat 1914/35 HMG
weapon.description: In many units the better Breda m37 HMG had not yet been issued on the outbreak of war. The less fortunate were stuck with the Mitriaglice ("Machinegun") Fiat 1914/35. This was a slightly modernised and re-calibred version of the unreliable Mitriaglice Fiat 14. The older gun was virtually designed to achieve regular jams, which the new version did not solve, instead adding a barrel-overheating problem.

weapon.name: 8mm Breda m37 HMG
weapon.description: The standard Italian heavy MG, this was used as a tank MG as well as in the infantry role. It was the best of a bad bunch, like most Italian MGs having a bizarre feed system - in this case, spent cartridge cases were placed back onto the feed tray, which then needed to be cleared before the weapon could be reloaded. It also had the usual Italian oiled-ammunition system which led to increased jamming, especially in dusty conditions.

weapon.name: 45mm lt mortar 45/5 m35
weapon.description: The 'Brixia' 45mm light mortar was the most unnecessarily-complicated light mortar of the war. It featured a number of novel but fairly useless innovations like a ten-round magazine (the rounds had to be taken out of the magazine, loaded by hand, and fired one at a time by a trigger). It also had a fully-featured aiming arrangement, though this was probably worthwhile since the tiny bomb fragmented very poorly and thus required careful aiming to be at all effective.

weapon.name: 0.55in Boys AT rifle
weapon.description: Issued to infantry platoons this heavy rifle had a vicious recoil that made it unpopular with the troops. By 1941 it was useless against AFVs but by firing into rocks, the heavy round would produce rock splinters that could cause some casualties to personnel.

weapon.name: PIAT AT launcher
weapon.description: Unlike the Bazooka and the Panzerfaust, the PIAT operated on the spigot mortar principle. Despite its punch it was unpopular due to its weight and the difficulty of cocking the main spring.

weapon.name: Bazooka RPG
weapon.description: One of the most original weapons of the war, the Bazooka and its off-shoots revolutionised the battle-field from early 1943. It provided infantry with a handy anti-tank capability, and 476,628 were produced during the war, plus 15,603,000 rockets.

weapon.name: 8mm St Etienne MMG
weapon.description: Overall a poor weapon, derived from the original Hotchkiss design. Fed by 24 or 30 round metal strips the gun had a variable rate of fire. Because of its heavy weight and tripod mount the St Etienne was not useful in a light machinegun role, and its magazine feed and tendency to overheat made it fairly useless in a sustained-fire medium machinegun role too.

weapon.name: Maxim 08 HMG (Belgian)
weapon.description: The Maxim 08 machine gun was Belgium’s standard machine gun for the infantry. Twelve of the 18 infantry divisions were equipped with Maxims. Six second-reserve infantry divisions were armed with the Colt machine gun. The two cavalry divisions and the two Chasseurs ardennais divisions used the Hotchkiss. Most of the Maxims in Belgian service were leftovers from World War I handed over by Germany after the armistice. The Maxim was a good, reliable weapon, but heavy and unwieldy

weapon.name: 13.2mm Hotchkiss HMG
weapon.description: The 13.2mm Mitrailleuse Hotchkiss d 13mm 2 Mle 1930 resembled an enlarged Bren gun, both in the overall shape and in the use of an overhead 30-round box magazine for feed. It was provided with a variety of mountings, including anti-tank/anti-personnel, anti-aircraft, and cavalry support. It was an expensive and complex weapon and was provided in small numbers to Greece and other countries.

weapon.name: 2cm Flak 38 - towed
weapon.description: Despite its decreasing effectiveness against heavily armoured aircraft such as the Thunderbolt this gun remained in service till the end. In 1944 there were more than 20,000.

weapon.name: 2cm Flak 38-SP
weapon.description: Many Flak 38s were mounted on a variety of vehicles. They provided valuable mobile direct firepower for infantry units as their effectiveness against newer Allied aircraft dropped away.

weapon.name: 2cm Flakvierling AA - towed
weapon.description: One of the most feared low-level anti-aircraft weapons of the war, the Flakvierling comprised four 2cm Flak 38s mounted together. It first appeared in 1940 and served to the end.

weapon.name: 2cm Flakvierling-SP
weapon.description: The Flakvierling was a terrifying weapon with devastating firepower. It was extremely successful in the SP role and could give awesome direct fire support to ground units.

weapon.name: 3.7cm Flak 36 - towed
weapon.description: This became the standard medium German flak gun and was adapted to a huge range of applications on trains, U-boats, flak towers and vehicles (as a self-propelled weapon).

weapon.name: 3.7cm Flak 36-SP
weapon.description: The Flak 36 was a versatile light flak gun and proved successful in a variety of roles, this one as a self-propelled weapon providing mobile flak and direct fire support for panzer units.

weapon.name: 7.5cm Flak L60
weapon.description: The 7.5cm Flak L60 was designed during the 1920s but turned down by the German War Office. Limited quantities were exported to Spain and Brazil. In 1939 undelivered guns were emplaced in coastal and fixed flak positions.

weapon.name: 8.8cm Flak 36
weapon.description: The Flak 18 and 36s were the most notorious weapons of the war. They were the dreaded "88s" which were used to such effect as anti-tank guns by Rommel in the desert.

weapon.name: 9.4cm Flak M39
weapon.description: Actually captured British 3.7in Vickers Anti-Aircraft guns.

weapon.name: 20mm Breda 20/65 m35 AA gun
weapon.description: This dual-purpose anti-tank and anti-aircraft weapon was, like many Italian weapons, unnecessarily complex. Particularly annoying was the manner in which it was built to carefully place spent ammunition cases back onto the loading plate, from which they would need to be cleared before reloading. The gun could be broken down for pack loading but more usually was towed by a light truck. Some of these were captured by the British in North Africa and pressed into service in hastily-re-roled field or AT artillery units that then became LAA troops.

weapon.name: 75mm Cannone 75/46 m34 AA gun
weapon.description: This was the standard Italian AA gun. Design work started in 1926 and the gun came into service in 1934. Despite the long pre-war period and the gun's reasonable performance, production was slow and by the end of 1942 only 226 of the 240 ordered had been delivered. In the anti-tank role it was roughly equivalent to the German 7.5cm PaK 40. The Germans took some over after 1943 and used them in towed and pedestal versions as the 7.5cm Flak 264/3 ( i ) and 7.5cm Flak 264/4 ( i ).

weapon.name: 90mm Cannone 90/53 AA gun
weapon.description: Equivalent to the famed German '88', this was the best anti-aircraft gun produced by Italy. Like the '88', it was often used in anti-tank and coastal-defence roles and proved effective. It was also mounted on the chassis of an M13/41 medium tank to form the Semovente M41M da 90/53.

weapon.name: 20mm Oerlikon AA gun
weapon.description: Originally a German design the Oelikon ended up being used by nearly all combatants. Despite its complexity it was highly effective, and was adapted to many variants.

weapon.name: 40mm Bofors AA gun
weapon.description: The most widely used AA gun of the war, the Swedish Bofors equipped medium AA units in the British Army.

weapon.name: 40mm Bofors AA gun - portee
weapon.description: The most widely used AA gun of the war, the Swedish Bofors equipped medium AA units in the British Army.

weapon.name: 3in AA gun
weapon.description: This described a range of 3-inch anti-aircraft guns, most modified from the original design brought into service in 1914. These modifications allowed the 3in AA to retain some usefulness through the early war. Although it was marked for retirement in 1941, its replacement did not eventuate and the 3in AA continued to serve until 1946.

weapon.name: 3.7in Vickers AA gun
weapon.description: Best classed as semi-mobile due to its great weight, even on wheeled mounts, the Vickers 3.7in AA gun was a reliable and effective weapon. It was also used by the Germans who captured several and even produced ammunition to keep them supplied.

weapon.name: 4.5in Mark II AA gun
weapon.description: Originally a twin-barreled Admiralty weapon, some of these were diverted for use in static land mountings by the Army. Part of the modification required removing the second barrel. Although the weapon was designated "4.5in", the actual calibre was 4.45in or 113mm. It was surrounded by a massive gun shield, which was in fact identical to that used on the navy ships.

weapon.name: 2cm sPzB 41 AT gun
weapon.description: This 2.8cm/2cm squeeze-bore weapon fired tungsten AP rounds at high velocity. The shortage of tungsten, and improvements in enemy armour, meant that this weapon had a very short useful service life.

weapon.name: 2cm sPzB 41 le AT gun
weapon.description: A reduced-weight paratroop version of the PanzerBuechse 41, this 2.8cm/2cm squeeze-bore weapon fired tungsten AP rounds at high velocity.

weapon.name: 3.7cm PaK 36 AT gun - towed
weapon.description: The basis for many anti-tank guns in service in 1939, the PaK 36 remained in service till the end despite its increasing ineffectiveness. By 1944 it was issued to reserve and training units.

weapon.name: 3.7cm PaK 36 AT gun-SP
weapon.description: The PaK 36 remained in service till the end despite its increasing ineffectiveness against Allied armour. Mounted on half-tracks it provided effective direct fire-support.

weapon.name: 4.7cm PaK 36 (t) AT gun - towed
weapon.description: The PaK 36 (t) was a Skoda 47mm kanon P.U.V. vz/36 L43.4, taken over after the annexation of Czechoslovakia. It was used as a towed piece and was also mounted on the PzKw I B chassis to form the first Panzerjaeger. Despite its antiquated looks it was a powerful and effective weapon during the early campaigns.

weapon.name: 4.7cm PaK 36 (t) AT gun-SP
weapon.description: The PaK 36 (t) was a Skoda 47mm kanon P.U.V. vz/36 L43.4, taken over after the annexation of Czechoslovakia. It was used as a towed piece and was also mounted on the PzKw I B chassis to form the first Panzerjaeger. Despite its antiquated looks it was a powerful and effective weapon during the early campaigns.

weapon.name: 5cm PaK 38 AT gun
weapon.description: The PaK 38 was an extremely successful gun in 1941-42. But by 1944 it equipped mainly reserve and training units.

weapon.name: 7.5cm PaK 40 AT gun
weapon.description: Really a scaled-up PaK 38, the 40 became the standard German aanti-tank gun and was used on all fronts. Though heavy it was a very potent weapon and was built in large numbers.

weapon.name: 7.62cm PaK 36 (r) AT gun-SP
weapon.description: This was a captured Russian Model 1936 field gun, used in some quantity by the Germans both in towed and self-propelled roles. The Germans went so far as to rebuild the gun, reboring the chamber to suit ammunition of their own (superior) design, moving the elevating handwheel to the left side of the gun, and adding a muzzle brake. This was considered one of the best AT guns produced during the war.

weapon.name: 20mm Soluthurn AT Rifle
weapon.description: Designed by the Swiss Soluthurn company for the Swiss Army and also supplied to Germany, Holland, Italy and Hungary, a small number of these weapons were captured by the Greeks after the Italians invaded. They were an effective weapon for the time, and could be fired without deploying the carriage.

weapon.name: 47mm Cannone 47/32 m35 AT gun
weapon.description: The 47mm Cannone da 47/32 m35 was the most common Italian anti-tank gun. It was a license-built version of the Austrian Boehler gun and was used for both AT work and for infantry support. It could be broken down into five loads for pack transport. Some were captured by the Greeks during the abortive Italian invasion.

weapon.name: 2pdr AT gun - towed
weapon.description: Theoretically the 2 pdr was capable of penetrating 44mm at 1000m. But it lacked an AP cap and frequently broke up on hardened plate so its capability has been reduced. Its max effective range was actually less than 500m.

weapon.name: 2pdr AT gun - portee
weapon.description: Theoretically the 2 pdr was capable of penetrating 44mm at 1000m. But it lacked an AP cap and frequently broke up on hardened plate so its capability has been reduced. Its max effective range was actually less than 500m. The portee 2pdrs were mounted on a 3t truck in a limited-traverse mounting, so they could be fired without deploying in an emergency. Normal procedure however was for the guns to be dismounted and dug in, where time permitted.

weapon.name: 6pdr AT gun
weapon.description: Developed as the replacement for the beleagured 2 pdr, the 6 pdr first appeared in numbers in the Battle of Gazala in May 1942. It was quickly overtaken by the appearance of the Tiger and was phased out of anti-tank regiments during 1943, although it continued to equip infantry anti-tank units.

weapon.name: 17pdr AT gun
weapon.description: The 17 pdr was developed to overcome the inadequacies of the 6 pdr. It was the only British gun to compete with the German long barrelled 75mm guns. It was also mounted in the Sherman Firefly.

weapon.name: 7.62mm DT LMG-AFV
weapon.description: This was a captured Soviet DT tank machine gun. It was fed by a 60-round drum magazine and had a reputation for being effectively and reliable.

weapon.name: 2cm Flakvierling-AFV
weapon.description: The Flakvierling was a terrifying weapon with devastating firepower. It was extremely successful in the SP role and could give awesome direct fire support to ground units.

weapon.name: 3.7cm Flak 36-AFV
weapon.description: The Flak 36 was a versatile light flak gun and proved successful in a variety of roles, this one as a self-propelled weapon providing mobile flak and direct fire support for panzer units.

weapon.name: 3.7cm KwK 36 L45 tank gun
weapon.description: The tank version of the Pak 36 3.7cm gun.

weapon.name: 4.7cm KwK 173 (f) tank gun
weapon.description: This was the German designation for the 47mm gun mounted in captured French tanks like the Char B1 and Somua S-35.

weapon.name: 37mm SA 18 L / 21 tank gun (H-35)
weapon.description: LOTB 37mm SA 18 L / 21 tank gun (H-35)

weapon.name: 7.62cm KwK L41.5 (r) tank gun
weapon.description: This was a captured Soviet 76.2mm L41.5 F-34 gun, firing modified German ammunition (which performed better than the original Soviet stock).

weapon.name: 8mm Breda M38 MG-AFV
weapon.description: Based on the standard Italian heavy MG, this tank version did fix one of the worst problems of the infantry model - instead of a rather ridiculous tray arrangement, it was fed by a conventional top-mounted box magazine.

weapon.name: 20mm Breda 20/65 m35 AA gun-AFV
weapon.description: This dual-purpose anti-tank and anti-aircraft weapon was, like many Italian weapons, unnecessarily complex. Particularly annoying was the manner in which it was built to carefully place spent ammunition cases back onto the loading plate, from which they would need to be cleared before reloading. The gun could be broken down for pack loading but more usually was towed by a light truck. Some of these were captured by the British in North Africa and pressed into service in hastily-re-roled field or AT artillery units that then became LAA troops.

weapon.name: 47mm Cannone 47/32 m35 AT gun-AFV
weapon.description: The 47mm Cannone da 47/32 m35 was the most common Italian anti-tank gun. It was a license-built version of the Austrian Boehler gun and was used for both AT work and for infantry support. It could be broken down into five loads for pack transport. Some were captured by the Greeks during the abortive Italian invasion. It was also mounted, as the Semovente L40 da 47/32, on a Carro Armato L6/40 chassis, and as a tank gun in its own right, in the M13/40 and M13/41 medium tanks.

weapon.name: 90mm Cannone 90/53 AA gun-AFV
weapon.description: Equivalent to the famed German '88', this was the best anti-aircraft gun produced by Italy. Like the '88', it was often used in anti-tank and coastal-defence roles and proved effective. It was also mounted on the chassis of an M13/41 medium tank to form the Semovente M41M da 90/53.

weapon.name: 102mm Cannone 102/35 Naval gun
weapon.description: This was an Italian Naval gun although it was often used in anti-tank and coastal-defence roles and proved effective. It was also mounted on the chassis of a Fiat 3-ton truck.

weapon.name: 2pdr tank gun
weapon.description: Theoretically the 2 pdr was capable of penetrating 44mm at 1000m. But it lacked an AP cap and frequently broke up on hardened plate so its capability has been reduced. Its max effective range was actually less than 500m.

weapon.name: 2pdr tank gun (A10)
weapon.description: Theoretically the 2 pdr was capable of penetrating 44mm at 1000m. But it lacked an AP cap and frequently broke up on hardened plate so its capability has been reduced. Its max effective range was actually less than 500m.

weapon.name: 2pdr tank gun (A13 Mk II)
weapon.description: Theoretically the 2 pdr was capable of penetrating 44mm at 1000m. But it lacked an AP cap and frequently broke up on hardened plate so its capability has been reduced. Its max effective range was actually less than 500m.

weapon.name: 3.7in tank mor
weapon.description: This weapon was used to equip the CS versions of the A9, A10 and A13 tanks. It fired smoke ammunition only.

weapon.name: 3.7in tank how
weapon.description: This was a more sophisticated tank howitzer capable of firing smoke, HE and HEAT (AP) ammunition. It was fitted to the CS versions of 6pdr-armed tanks - the Centaur IV, Cromwell VI and VIII, Churchill V and VIII, and Alecto I.

weapon.name: 3.7in tank how (A15)
weapon.description: This was a more sophisticated tank howitzer capable of firing smoke, and HE ammunition. It was fitted to the CS versions of the A15.

weapon.name: 15cm Nebelwerfer
weapon.description: This was the standard weapon of Nebelwerfer batteries after entering service in 1942. It was a simple system but delivered devastating firepower.

weapon.name: 7.5cm leGeb IG 18 mtn gun
weapon.description: Principal support gun for German mountain infantry regiments. Short barrel 75mm Howitzer delivering a 6kg shell. This was a leIG 18 adapted to be broken down into several loads for manpack carriage.

weapon.name: 7.5cm leIG 18 inf gun
weapon.description: Principal support gun for German infantry regiments. Short barrel 75mm Howitzer delivering a 6kg shell.

weapon.name: 7.5cm leIG 18 inf gun (indirect)
weapon.description: Principle support gun for German infantry regiments. Short barrel 75mm Howitzer delivering a 6kg shell.

weapon.name: 7.5cm leIG 18 inf gun-SP
weapon.description: Principle support gun for German infantry regiments. Short barrel 75mm Howitzer delivering a 6kg shell.

weapon.name: 15cm sIG 33 inf gun
weapon.description: This short barrel 150mm Howitzer delivered a 38kg shell and provided the much needed heavy firepower support for German Inf Regts.

weapon.name: 15cm sIG 33 inf gun (indirect)
weapon.description: This short barrel 150mm Howitzer delivered a 38kg shell and provided the much needed heavy firepower support for German Inf Regts.

weapon.name: 15cm sIG 33 inf gun-SP
weapon.description: This short barrel 150mm Howitzer delivered a 38kg shell and provided the much needed heavy firepower support for German Inf Regts.

weapon.name: 47mm Cannone 47/32 m35 gun
weapon.description: The 47mm Cannone da 47/32 m35 was the most common Italian anti-tank gun. It was a license-built version of the Austrian Boehler gun and was used for both AT work and for infantry support. It could be broken down into five loads for pack transport. Some were captured by the Greeks during the abortive Italian invasion.

weapon.name: 65mm Cannone 65/17 gun
weapon.description: First produced in 1913, this was still in use in most infantry regiments on the invasion of Greece. Although there was an AP round produced for anti-tank work, it was ineffective and not commonly used. The weapon could be broken down into six loads for manpack transport.

weapon.name: 7.5cm LG 40 recoilless gun
weapon.description: Called a "light metal" gun by the Allies, the LG40 was a revolutionary weapon for its time, working on the recently developed recoilless principle. It was sufficiently light to be issued to parachute and mountain troops as both an infantry gun and a artillery support weapon.

weapon.name: 7.5cm GebG 36 mtn gun
weapon.description: The Gebirgsgeschuetz 36 was the standard gun of the mountain batteries. It could be broken down into several loads for transport by manpack or mule. It was used throughout the war and was popular with its crews.

weapon.name: 7.5cm FK 257 (i) gun
weapon.description: Originally the Cannone da 75/27 modello 06, this light field piece was taken over by the Germans.

weapon.name: 10cm leFH 14/19 (t) how
weapon.description: This was originally the Skoda 100mm Model 14/19 howitzer. After Czechoslovakia was taken over by Germany, many of these guns entered German service. They were also used by the Italians as the Obice da 100/24.

weapon.name: 10.5cm LG 40 recoilless gun
weapon.description: Called a "light metal" gun by the Allies, the LG40 was a revolutionary weapon for its time, working on the recently developed recoilless principle. It was sufficiently light to be issued to parachute and mountain troops as both an infantry gun and a artillery support weapon. This 10.5cm version was simply an upscaled copy of the original 7.5cm LG40. It could be dropped by parachute in four separate loads, or could be delivered in a Gotha Go 242 glider together with its SdKfz 2 Kettenkrad prime mover. It was issued with standard HE ammunition and an anti-armour hollow-charge shell.

weapon.name: 10.5cm GebH 40 mtn how
weapon.description: An advanced and unusual design, the 10.5cm Gebirgshaubitze ( mountain howitzer ) 40 was issued to the heavy batteries of mountain divisions.

weapon.name: 10.5cm sK 18 gun
weapon.description: The sK 18 was intended as the standard medium piece but was supplanted by the sFH 18. Still, many were built and proved very useful in the dark days of late 1944.

weapon.name: 10.5cm K 339 (j) gun
weapon.description: Renamed captured Yugoslavian Skoda 105mm Model 35 field guns, used by the Germans for various tasks including coastal defence.

weapon.name: 10.5cm leFH 18M how
weapon.description: While it looked clumsy with its big wheels, this was a very good piece which threw a big shell, though not quite far enough. It remained the standard German field piece throughout the war, equipping two artillery battalions in most divisions.

weapon.name: 15cm sFH 18 how
weapon.description: This was the standard German medium piece, equipping one battalion in each division. It was a good weapon, though a little out-ranged by its Allied counterparts.

weapon.name: 15.5cm K 420 (f) gun
weapon.description: Renamed from a captured French Canon de 155 L mle 1916 St Chamond gun and mainly used for coastal defence.

weapon.name: 17cm K18 gun
weapon.description: Excellent long range gun. Developed in 1941. Each SS Pz Div had one battalion of these guns.

weapon.name: 21cm langer Mrs how
weapon.description: Brought in service in 1916, this Krupp Moerser (heavy howitzer) was designed for static warfare. Although the design was changed in 1939 to enable the gun to be moved in a single load, it was still cumbersome and was eventually relegated to static defence duties only.

weapon.name: 21cm Mrs 18 how
weapon.description: Entering service in 1939, the Mrs (short for "Moerser") 18 heavy howitzer was a useful piece with a variety of ammunition types and the ability to fire over a wide spread of ranges. Production was halted in 1942 in favour of the 17cm K18, but enough of the M18 had already been produced for it to see service in numbers on all fronts. Setting up the gun was quite slow as it had to be transported in two separate loads.

weapon.name: 75mm Obice 75/13 how
weapon.description: Originally the Skoda 75mm Model 15, this was one of the best and most widely-used mountain guns of the period. It served under various designations in the armies of Czechoslovakia, Austria, Hungary, Rumania, Bulgaria, and Turkey. Many were captured and used by the Italians as the Obice 75/13, and by the Germans as the 7.5cm GebK (Gebirgskanone or "mountain gun") 259 ( i ) (for guns from Italy) and as the 7.5cm GebK 15 (for guns from the Czechs, Austrians, Poland and Yugoslavia.

weapon.name: 75mm Obice 75/18 m34 how-SP
weapon.description: Although only produced in very small numbers, this light field piece was in fact highly effective and formed the basis for the Semovente M40 and M41 da 75/18. After the Italian surrender, the Germans took over as many of these guns as they could, calling them the 7.5cm leFH 255 ( i ).

weapon.name: 75mm Obice 75/18 m35 how
weapon.description: Although only produced in very small numbers, this light field piece was in fact highly effective and formed the basis for the Semovente M40 and M41 da 75/18. After the Italian surrender, the Germans took over as many of these guns as they could, calling them the 7.5cm leFH 255 ( i ).

weapon.name: 75mm Cannone 75/27 gun
weapon.description: These Italian guns were awful - particularly their ammunition which was shipped in as many as five separate pieces that had to be assembled before firing. Some were captured by the British and formed part of a 100-gun shipment sent to Crete by Wavell, with the regret that he could not spare more. It is unlikely he really regretted the loss of these weapons, especially since in many cases the guns arrived without sights.

weapon.name: 100mm Obice 100/17 how
weapon.description: Manufactured by Skoda as the 100mm Model 14, these weapons had been produced for Austria-Hungary during World War I and taken over by Italy in 1918.

weapon.name: 105mm Cannone 105/32 gun
weapon.description: Manufactured by Skoda as the 105mm Model 15, these weapons had been produced for Austria-Hungary during World War I and taken over by Italy in 1918. The guns were originally 104mm calibre but were bored out to 105mm to enable standard Italian ammunition to be used.

weapon.name: 149mm Obice 149/19 how
weapon.description: Manufactured in three slightly different versions, the 149mm Obice da 149/19 modello 37, 41 and 42 was highly regarded by the Italian artillerymen who believed it superior to equivalent Allied pieces. As with most Italian artillery, the modernisation program that introduced it was handicapped by poor production rates and the full order was never met.

weapon.name: 75mm Canon m1897 gun
weapon.description: Manufactured by the US as the M1897, and adopted in small numbers by Britain as the Ordnance QF 75mm Mark I, a few of these found their way to Crete.

weapon.name: 75mm Canon m1897 gun (direct fire)
weapon.description: Manufactured by the US as the M1897, and adopted in small numbers by Britain as the Ordnance QF 75mm Mark I, a few of these found their way to Crete. Many of those shipped to Crete lacked sights and could only be used in direct fire, by aiming down the barrel.

weapon.name: 75mm Cannone 75/27 gun (direct fire)
weapon.description: These captured Italian pieces were part of a 100-gun shipment sent to Crete by Wavell, with the regret that he could not spare more. They were awful - particularly their ammunition which was shipped in as many as five separate pieces that had to be assembled before firing - and in many cases the guns arrived without sights.

weapon.name: 18pdr gun
weapon.description: First issued in 1904 this was a dependable and effective, but totally obsolete, weapon. While some were bored out to become the 25pdr Mk 1 (also called the 18/25pdr), others were captured by the Germans at Dunkirk and used for coastal defence, and a few were taken to Malta by 12th Fd Regt RA. When that unit re-equipped with 25pdr guns, the 18pdrs were taken over by the Royal Malta Artillery and used for beach defence.

weapon.name: 25pdr Mk 1 gun
weapon.description: The initial development of the 25pdr was hindered by the large number of obsolete but still useable 18pdr guns in the Royal Artillery's inventory. When the need for field artillery firing a heavier shell was finally acknowledged, the quickest solution was to rebore the 18pdr barrels to take the bigger ammunition. This version, usually called the 18/25pdr, equipped British and Commonwealth artillery units until the arrival of the now-famous 25pdr Mk 2.

weapon.name: 25pdr Mk 2 gun
weapon.description: Probably the popular artillery piece of the war, the 25 pdr was incredibly versatile and effective. More than 12,000 were built during the war. This was the standard gun of field regiments.

weapon.name: 100mm Obice 100/17 (captured)
weapon.description: Manufactured by Skoda as the 100mm Model 14, these weapons had been produced for Austria-Hungary during World War I and taken over by Italy in 1918. They were captured by the British at Tobruk and then shipped to Crete. They were not well-regarded by the British and Commonwealth troops who had to use them due to their short range and awful ammunition. Some of these problems may have been self-imposed as data for the same guns in Italian service suggests a greater range than that achieved by the British.

weapon.name: 4.5in Mk 2 gun
weapon.description: The 4.5" was developed alongside the 5.5" in the late 1930s. It was unpopular due to the poor HE filling of the shell (only 1.76kg) and priority shifted to the 5.5". The 4.5" nevertheless remained in service throughout the war.

weapon.name: 4.5in Mk 1 gun
weapon.description: This gun was introduced as a low-cost measure to modernise the Royal Artillery's Medium Regiments during the mid-1930s. It was essentially a 60pdr gun with a new barrel and pneumatic tyres. It was a reasonable piece however, and in 1940 was probably the best medium gun used by the BEF.

weapon.name: 60pdr Mk II how
weapon.description: A WWI design, the 60pdr was obsolete by the start of WWII, but still provided a small part of the British Medium Artillery. 16 of the guns were used in France in 1940, and although the Germans took them briefly into service, their true quality was recognised and they were recycled as scrap metal.

weapon.name: 5.5in gun
weapon.description: The 5.5 entered service in 1941 and became the best medium British piece of the war. It was very versatile and served both as a gun and howitzer in medium regiments.

weapon.name: 6in how
weapon.description: Originally produced in 1915 the 6in howitzer was well outdated at the start of WWII. However, they still formed the backbone of the Royal Artillery's Medium Regiments and continued to do so until the introduction of newer equipment throughout 1941.

weapon.name: 7.2in how
weapon.description: After Dunkirk the British Army had almost no heavy artillery. This weapon was actually an 8" barrel relined to 7.2". It was a poor weapon. The recoil was so strong it had to be relaid every shot, giving a very slow rate of fire.

weapon.name: 75mm M1A1 pack how
weapon.description: A variant of the 75mm howitzer. For the airborne role the gun was mounted on the lighter M8 carriage. A little light on for shell weight and range but an excellent weapon

weapon.name: 105mm M3 pack how
weapon.description: Oiginally a shortened version of the 105mm M2 field howitzer, the M3 entered service in 1943 and served in all theatres. It was used only by US forces. 2,580 were built during the war.

weapon.name: 155mm M1A1 how
weapon.description: First issued in 1942, by 1945 4035 had been built. The 155 was renowned for its accuracy. It was also the lightest of the principal medium pieces.

weapon.name: 65mm Canon M m1906 gun
weapon.description: Designed for use by French mountain troops, some examples of this unusual gun were passed to the Greek Army and saw service in the Greek Infantry Divisions. The gun could be broken into four separate loads for transport by pack animals. The "M" stood for "montagne" or "mountain".

weapon.name: 75mm Skoda Model 15 gun
weapon.description: This was one of the best and most widely-used mountain guns of the period. It served under various designations in the armies of Czechoslovakia, Austria, Hungary, Rumania, Bulgaria, Turkey and Greece. Many were captured and used by the Italians as the Obice 75/13, and by the Germans as the 7.5cm GebK (Gebirgskanone or "mountain gun") 259 ( i ) (for guns from Italy) and as the 7.5cm GebK 15 (for guns from the Czechs, Austrians, Poland and Yugoslavia.

weapon.name: 75mm Skoda Model 15 gun - portee
weapon.description: This was one of the best and most widely-used mountain guns of the period. It served under various designations in the armies of Czechoslovakia, Austria, Hungary, Rumania, Bulgaria, Turkey and Greece. Many were captured and used by the Italians as the Obice 75/13, and by the Germans as the 7.5cm GebK (Gebirgskanone or "mountain gun") 259 ( i ) (for guns from Italy) and as the 7.5cm GebK 15 (for guns from the Czechs, Austrians, Poland and Yugoslavia.

weapon.name: 75mm Krupp M.06 gun
weapon.description: These guns, although quite obsolete, were still in use with several nations including both Italy and Greece at the start of WWII. This particular gun was the same as the 75mm Cannone 75/27 in use with the Italians.

weapon.name: 85mm Canon m1927 gun
weapon.description: Designated in full the Canon de 85 mle 1927 Schneider, a small number of these guns were delivered to the Greek Army before the outbreak of war and used in their medium batteries.

weapon.name: 105mm Canon m1927 gun
weapon.description: Designated in full the Canon de 105 mle 25/27 Schneider, a small number of these guns were delivered to the Greek Army before the outbreak of war and used in their heavy batteries.

weapon.name: 155mm Canon m1917 gun
weapon.description: Designed to suit the conditions of the Western Front in 1917, the Canon de 155 C mle 1917 Schneider was one of the best pieces in its class to come out of WWI. It was subsequently exported to many countries, including Greece, where it formed the mainstay of the tiny Greek heavy artillery arm. It was still in service with many nations on the outbreak of WWII, including Russia, where it was modified to 152mm calibre.

weapon.name: 5cm leGrW 36 lt mortar
weapon.description: 5cm leGrW 36 lt mortar

weapon.name: 8cm kGrW 42 mortar
weapon.description: The kurzer Granatwerfer 42 ( short mortar model 42 ) was designed for airborne units. Its extremely short range meant it was often used in the role previously fulfilled by the 5cm leichte Granatwerfer 36 ( light mortar model 36 ). It was also known as the Stummelwerfer or "stump mortar".

weapon.name: 8cm sGrW 34 mortar
weapon.description: The schwerer Granatwerfer 34 ( heavy mortar model 34 ) was the standard German infantry mortar.

weapon.name: 10cm NW 35 mortar
weapon.description: The 10cm Nebelwerfer 35 ( smoke projector model 35 ) was a scaled-up 105mm version of the 8cm GrW 34. Mainly used by chemical troops for smoke screening, the mortar also fired a useful HE bomb over a moderate range.

weapon.name: 12cm GrW 42 mortar
weapon.description: The 12cm Granatwerfer 42 ( mortar model 42 ) was a direct copy of a Russian 120mm mortar. It was extremely effective and even replaced infantry guns in the support companies of some infantry regiments and battalions.

weapon.name: 81mm 81/14 m35 mortar
weapon.description: This Italian weapon was a copy of the French 81mm mortar. It outranged the British 3in mortar but fired a less effective bomb.

radio.name: FuG.b1
radio.description: Widely used by all arms except inf.

ammo.name: 30 cal
ammo.description: Standard ammo for US Garand rifle, M1 carbine and 30 cal LMG.

ammo.name: PzFaust warhead
ammo.description: The Panzerfaust was actually a single-shot throw away weapon but the wonders of modern technology dictate that it be treated in the same way as Bazookas and PIATs.

ammo.name: PzSchreck AP
ammo.description: PzSchreck rocket - division into AP/HE types reflects reserving some rockets for use on tanks.

ammo.name: PzSchreck HE
ammo.description: PzSchreck rocket - division into AP/HE types reflects reserving some rockets for use on tanks.
